# What is an Array?

- Array is a data structure which stores a collection of homogeneous items (that homogeneous items can be of any data type like array of integers, array of char, array of bool etc)

- It has contiguous memory (data or processes are stored in adjacent or sequential memory locations, without any gaps or breaks)
# Representation

dominant-baseline="alphabetic">index 4</text></g></svg>

We can access the elements of an array with the help of an index.

What is an index? Index is location of every element stored in an array.

In C++, the indexing starts from 0

# Syntax for Array Declaration

```txt
datatype array_name [array_size]
```

For e.g.

```cpp
int array[5]; // declaring an array of size 5
```
## To specify elements in the array

```cpp
// this is how we declare an array
int array[] = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}
```

**NOTE**: In the above example, if we are initialising the array then there is no need for stating the size of array. 

# Memory Allocation in Arrays

```cpp
int array[5];
```

x="0" y="67.62" font-family="Excalifont, Xiaolai, Segoe UI Emoji" font-size="20px" fill="#2f9e44" text-anchor="start" style="white-space: pre;" direction="ltr" dominant-baseline="alphabetic">size = 5 * 4 = 20 bytes</text></g></svg>
For,

```cpp
char alphabets[26];

// size of an array of characters with 26 size
// char = 1 byte
// size of an array = 1 * 26 = 26 bytes
```

# Accessing element in single dimensional array

## 0-based indexing

```cpp
int array[] = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5}

// accessing the element of array
array[0] // which has value 1 
array[1] // which has value 2 
array[2] // which has value 3 
array[3] // which has value 4 
array[4] // which has value 5 
```

## Assigning the elements in array

```cpp
int array[5];

array[0] = 2; // for the 0th index, element 2 is stored
```

# Size operation in Arrays

To know the size of array, we use `sizeof()`.

To know the length of array we use `sizeof(array)/sizeof(array[0])`
